block.p: Group of 7's List Names Money-Laundering Nations The leading industrial nations took the unprecedented step of naming 15 countries, including Israel, Russia and the Philippines, as potential havens for ill-gotten wealth.

Group of 7's List Names Money-Laundering Nations The leading industrial nations took the unprecedented step of naming 15 countries, including Israel, Russia and the Philippines, as potential havens for ill-gotten wealth.

AIDS Moves Into Rural Areas A report by Unaids and the Food and Agricultural Organization says the global AIDS epidemic, long thought an urban phenomenon, is shifting to rural areas in the third world.

Israeli Coalition Holds Shas retracted its resignation from the government, leaving Prime Minister Ehud Barak's broad coalition battered but intact as it heads into a crucial stage of peacemaking with the Palestinians.

Warning to Americans in Jordan The American Embassy in Jordan issued a warning that it had ''information concerning terrorist targeting'' of the embassy and could not rule out the possibility of attacks on American citizens in the country.

U.S.-China Relations Improved The United States and China officially declared during a visit by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that they had entered an era of improved relations. But both sides said they were now focused on the sensitive issue of Taiwan and the Clinton administration's plans for an antimissile defensive shield.

Troubled Zimbabwe Elections Election monitors say large-scale problems with voter registration, overshadowed by the political violence that has dogged Zimbabwe for months, remain unresolved and may lead to confusion when voters go to the polls this weekend.

Kosovo Tribunal Planned The head of the United Nations mission in Kosovo plans to create a court to try war and ethnic crimes in the province, according to an official in his agency. The proposed tribunal would be led by international judges and prosecutors and supplemented by equal numbers of Albanian, Serbian and other ethnic judges.
British Charge Dutch Driver Perry Wacker, the Dutch driver of a truck that became the sealed tomb of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants to Britain, was charged with multiple counts of manslaughter.

Justice Dept. Lawyer Urges Special Counsel for Gore The head of the Justice Department's campaign finance unit recommended that Attorney General Janet Reno appoint a special counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore's political fund-raising activities in 1996, officials said.
Mr. Gore visited a Minnesota school with Gov. Jesse Ventura.
Nader Rocks Gore's Boat Democratic and Republican strategists say Ralph Nader has emerged as more politically potent than Patrick Buchanan and may affect Vice President Al Gore's candidacy.

No Charges in Travel Firings An independent counsel said he would seek no criminal charges against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the firing of seven longtime White House travel office employees in 1993. But the prosecutor said there was substantial evidence that she had played a larger role than she portrayed in sworn testimony.

Texas Execution Carried Out Texas executed Gary Graham, who was convicted of a 1981 murder, although 5 of the 18 members of the state parole board had urged that the execution not be carried out and the United States Supreme Court was sharply divided on hearing a last-minute appeal. Gov. George W. Bush did not intervene.
G.O.P. Disclosure Legislation The House Ways and Means Committee approved a Republican-written bill to require tax-exempt groups that conduct political advocacy to disclose donors and spending.
Democratic Drug Bill Fails Senate Democrats forced a vote on their prescription drug plan, a politically potent issue on the campaign trail, but the measure was swiftly defeated by Republicans.

Split Decision on H.M.O.'s A federal appeals court has upheld a Texas law letting patients sue H.M.O.'s in state court for medical malpractice, but it struck a provision that gave patients the right to an independent review of H.M.O. decisions on benefits or coverage.
Online Pornography Ruling An appellate court upheld a lower-court order against enforcing a federal law intended to shield children from online pornography.

Addicts Who Commit Crime May Get Treatment, Not Jail New York will become the first state to require that nearly all nonviolent criminals who are drug addicts be offered treatment instead of jail time, under changes announced by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye that are intended to ease inmate crowding.

Prosecutor's Husband Guilty A federal jury convicted Albert J. Pirro Jr. of conspiracy and tax evasion. Mr. Pirro, 53, an influential Republican businessman, is married to Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney in Westchester County. He could receive up to four years in prison, according to sentencing guidelines.
Consensus in Albany Governor Pataki and legislators agreed on a package of gun controls and to overhaul sex-crime laws.
Inquiry Into Lazio Investments The S.E.C. is investigating whether Representative Rick A. Lazio violated insider trading laws in 1997.
Rent Increase Approved The Rent Guidelines Board approved a 4 percent rise for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year leases.

Compromise on Meteorite The American Museum of Natural History and an Indian group reached an agreement that would let the 15.5-ton Willamette Meteorite remain a centerpiece of the museum's new center for Earth and space.
Dinosaur-Bird Theory Doubts Scientists said fossil evidence of the oldest known feathered animal challenged the theory that birds had evolved from dinosaurs.
Tantalizing Photos of Mars Pictures taken by NASA's Mars Global Surveyor are leading scientists to surmise that Mars may have reservoirs of liquid water hidden under parts of its icy surface.
Flu Vaccine to Be Late Officials said influenza vaccine shipments would be delayed this fall and there might be shortages because of manufacturing problems.
No Response to OPEC Action Oil prices showed no sign of retreating a day after OPEC decided to increase production, and lawmakers stepped up calls for inquiries into gasoline ''price gouging.''

Microsoft's New Vision Microsoft unveiled a strategy that would move its business away from the personal computer and toward a new generation of Internet-based software that would allow people to interact with data and each other via computers, digital cell phones or interactive televisions.

Tentative Deal for Gonzalez The Yankees agreed in principle to acquire the Detroit slugger Juan Gonzalez for outfielder Ricky Ledee and two minor leaguers. But Gonzalez can veto the deal. The Yanks were still negotiating with the Chicago Cubs for Sammy Sosa.
New Voices on 'Monday Night' The comic Dennis Miller and the former N.F.L. quarterback Dan Fouts will join Al Michaels in the booth of ''Monday Night Football.''
